sentences.sentence: I’ve been seeing some blatant hypocrisy from both conservative and libertarian friends of mine, and I think it’s time to discuss what Net Neutrality is, and why it may be useful in the long run.
Now I’m probably going to get the “you’re not a real libertarian” nonsense, so let’s get definitions out of the way.
Libertarianism as outlined by Wikipedia is: ( : libertas , “freedom”) is a collection of political philosophies and movements that uphold liberty as a core principle.
Libertarians seek to maximize political freedom and autonomy, emphasizing freedom of choice, voluntary association, individual judgment and self-ownership.
Libertarians share a skepticism of authority and state power.
However, they diverge on the scope of their opposition to existing political and economic systems.

Various schools of libertarian thought offer a range of views regarding the legitimate functions of state and private power, often calling for the restriction or dissolution of coercive social institutions.
In essence libertarianism is about individualism and liberty.
This is why I call myself one, as I always defend rights and freedoms.
This is why I approach Net Neutrality from a very specific lens; I’m always looking for how legislation upholds freedom or destroys it, and I feel Net Neutrality supports it.

I’ll outline this later, but first, let me deconstruct some of the arguments I’ve seen constantly made against Net Neutrality “The internet will be the same as in 2015.” I’ve seen this statement a significant number of times, as some sort of appeal to tradition, and this statement is deceptively true, and untrue.
Yes the internet will now be the same as 2015, however, this doesn’t have the seemingly positive connotations being assigned to it.
First, now and back in 2015, there were extreme corporate monopolies by Internet Service Providers (ISPs).

This has been the case since after 2005, when the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ended regulations to label ISPs as “common carriers,” though they allowed for the decision for communities to work off of this system.
This system outlined that since the internet was a public service, all of the data had to be treated equally, irrelevant of how much bandwidth was used at the time.

This wasn’t a major problem as the internet was extremely limited at the time, but the larger implication of this was that internet providers at the time had to share poles to distribute their services.
This effectively stated that “any startup can have the same ability to be as successful as an established provider.” This sounds ironic.
A freer market, through regulation.
ISPs began lobbying communities and states to gain effective rights to hold monopolies on the distribution of the internet in their areas.
They effectively prevented startups from being able to exist, which actively destroyed competition.
They then grew their networks, and solidified their monopolies.
All of this was long before Net Neutrality.
We can see even from 2011 that large corporations already had monopolies, in a system without Net Neutrality, and this didn’t change after its implementation.
US ISP broadband internet subscribers 2011-2017 .

Lets change “ISPs” with “government.” “[The] government would never silence, censor, or throttle certain sites or individuals.” I don’t understand this, libertarians typically dislike authority, at least when the power of that authority grows so large that the interests of the people are no longer relevant.
If we’re going to be logically consistent, this also should apply to massive companies, who do not have the public’s best interests at the core of their decisions.

When an ISP controls 100% of the market share in a city (as is the case for some 129 million Americans, 40% of the populace), they have absolutely no responsibility to the interests of their consumers.
They can do anything they want, and they still will hold the entirety of the market.
This doesn’t change without Net Neutrality — if anything, it gets worse.
Now, companies are given the ability to discriminate data traffic.
One must be truly disconnected from reality to make such an assertion.
These corporations are profit-driven, and to think they’re going to let a competitor have the chance to get any market share would be absurd.
This, however, shows hypocrisy.
All of these conservatives and libertarians I have seen have expressed anger for Google, Facebook, Reddit, Twitter, and Youtube, for silencing “right-wing” content.
They have a point; these companies shouldn’t be able to police speech that doesn’t break the law.
Content that argues for terrorism, like that of ISIS, or content that argues for genocide (of any group of people, yes this includes white people), ought to be prevented.
(If this concept confuses you, read my article here ).
This comes from people who hold Orwell’s 1984 to the same standard as I, one of a clear indicator of what happens when speech is no longer free.
Either we’re logically consistent and say, “no company can police speech or throttle content they disagree with on an ideological basis,” or they all can, and we can’t get angry at them.
ISP’s are no better than Goolag.
“This will make a free market” Again, another argument I do not understand.
I previously outlined how Net Neutrality was not the cause of the monopolies, nor is removing it the solution.
So I want to touch on what Ben Shapiro said .
Currently there are different internet prices for different speeds.
If you’re a grandma who uses email, and browses the web, you can buy internet for a far cheaper price than your all-inclusive 100mbps down/up (or higher) fiber optic that many households use.
This doesn’t discriminate what data you’re looking at, but it gives you a static speed to view it at.
It’s possible that the ISP will make a package, where you get Hulu for $5 a month, but any alternative is $15 (possibly inclusive, though this could be per competitor.)
We want a balance of competition in each space, but that can’t occur if the corporation favors a different corporation for a certain service, and discriminates against their competitors.
Take it a step further, now advertisements from competitors for “some unknown reason” load extremely slowly, or the page is prevented from loading.
The answer is it can’t.
This makes it seem like seem like a system where data is treated equally is the best possible system for the internet.
Experts seem to agree.
Ironically, the market is more free for the individual, when regulations are in place.

So this begs the question “who is Ajit Pai representing?” It sure doesn’t look like he represents anything but corporate interests, for which he was a lawyer , before being appointed to the commission.
Libertarians ought to be mad at politicians representing interests that aren’t those of the people, for liberty.
They also should be mad at bureaucrats, who weren’t elected, who also work to destroy liberty.
Net Neutrality entails much more than it would seem.
It effectively protects your ability to access this article.
It allows for me to have my voice heard, without any ability for it to be throttled, silenced, or removed an ISP.
And we ought to fight to defend the freedom to actively create and view content in a non-restrictive manner.
If you are interested in fighting for Net Neutrality, click here, and call your governmental representatives.
